DOC.HEAD: Weather Forces Sixth Delay in Martin Marietta Launch
DOC.TEXT: Blustery cold weather and high upper-level winds Tuesday forced Martin Marietta Corp. to postpone its first commercial rocket launch for a sixth time. Wednesday's scheduled launch of the Titan 3, with British and Japanese communications satellites aboard, has been rescheduled to 7:05 p.m. EST Thursday, said Martin Marietta spokesman Robert V. Gordon. ``Air currents in the upper atmosphere are too strong'' and recent near-freezing temperatures were too low for the Titan 3 to be launched safely, Gordon said. Wednesday's lows for the Cape Canaveral area were expected to be in the 40s, which would chill the Titan 3's solid fuel boosters to levels that are unacceptable for launching. Temperatures ``need to be in the 60s,'' he said. The rocket will carry Skynet 4A, a satellite for the British Defense Ministry, and JCSAT-2, a satellite for the Japanese Satellite Communications Co. Martin Marietta has been trying to launch the Titan 3 since Dec. 7. The company's foray into the highly competitive international commercial space business has been delayed four times due to bad weather and once because of a computer software problem.
